protocol_name: FVIC (Frequency of Visibly Infected Cells) Protocol
protocol_name_html: FVIC (Frequency of Visibly Infected Cells) Protocol
description: Purpose: This protocol describes how to pellet bacterial cells onto grids and stain them so that viruses can be visualized within the cells using transmission electron microscopy. Data obtained from these grids can be used to calculate the frequency of visibly infected cells (FVIC), the frequency of infected cells (FIC), the fraction of mortality due to viral lysis (FMVL), and burst size.
warning: *Caution: uranyl acetate is toxic so read the MSDS and use a lab coat, eye protection, respiratory mask, and gloves when handling it in powdered form.
protocol_affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona/Ohio State University

authors_list.name: Jennifer Brum
authors_list.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona/Ohio State University

guidelines:
Materials required:
- glow discharge apparatus
- ultracentrifuge and rotor capable of 55000 xg
- pollyallomer ultracentrifuge tubes with epoxy in the bottom to provide a flat surface
- EM grid-grade forceps
- EM grids (formvar coated 200 mesh copper grids)
- paper dividers from between commercially packaged filters
- double-sided tape
- razor blade
- uranyl acetate
- ultra-purified water such as Milli-Q water
- petri dish
- 4x 2 ml microcentrifuge tubes with screw caps
- 4 ml plastic culture tube with cap
- small stir bar
- stir plate
- filter paper (cut into wedges)
- 0.02 µm syringe filter and syringe (3-5 ml)
- lab coat, respiratory protection (mask), eye protection
- timer
- transmission electron microscope

Applicable References:

Proctor and Fuhrman (1990) – The original description of the FVIC method.

Binder (1999) – The equations used to calculate FIC and FMVL, and the assumptions inherent in those equations.

Brum et al. (2005) – An example of a use of the FVIC method to investigate viral induced mortality of bacteria in an aquatic ecosystem.

Binder, B. (1999) Reconsidering the relationship between virally induced bacterial mortality and the frequency of infected cells. Aquatic Microbial Ecology 18: 207-215.

Brum, J.R., Steward, G.F., Jiang, S.C., and Jellison, R. (2005) Spatial and temporal variability of prokaryotes, viruses, and viral infections of prokaryotes in an alkaline, hypersaline lake. Aquatic Microbial Ecology 41: 247-260.

Proctor, L.M., and Fuhrman, J.A. (1990) Viral mortality of marine bacteria and cyanobacteria. Nature 343: 60-62.

components.data: On the same day of grid prep, use glow discharge to render grids hydrophilic.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: On the same day of grid prep, use glow discharge to render grids hydrophilic.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Cut a circle out of a paper filter divider such that it has a diameter slightly smaller than the interior diameter of the ultracentrifuge tubes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Cut a circle out of a paper filter divider such that it has a diameter slightly smaller than the interior diameter of the ultracentrifuge tubes.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Cut small rectangles (~3 mm x 1 mm) of double-sided tape using a razor blade.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Cut small rectangles (~3 mm x 1 mm) of double-sided tape using a razor blade.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data:
Attach the discharged grids (shiny-side-up) to the circle of paper using the double-sided tape such that only the edge of the grids contacts the tape (Figure 1)



Figure 1:Grids attached to the paper filter divider with double-sided tape.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Attach the discharged grids (shiny-side-up) to the circle of paper using the double-sided tape such that only the edge of the grids contacts the tape (Figure 1)



Figure 1:Grids attached to the paper filter divider with double-sided tape.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data:
Insert the paper with the attached grids into the ultracentrifuge tube grids-side-up (Figure 2) 



Figure 2.  Grids inserted into the bottom of the ultracentrifuge tube.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Insert the paper with the attached grids into the ultracentrifuge tube grids-side-up (Figure 2) 



Figure 2.  Grids inserted into the bottom of the ultracentrifuge tube.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Add your sample to the ultracentrifuge tube ensuring that there are no air bubbles under the circle of paper.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add your sample to the ultracentrifuge tube ensuring that there are no air bubbles under the circle of paper.

source_data.annotation: Note: ca. 20 ml of sample is required for samples with bacterial concentrations of 10<sup>7</sup> ml<sup>-1</sup>. Adjust the sample volume according to the bacterial concentration in your samples.
source_data.thread_text: Note: ca. 20 ml of sample is required for samples with bacterial concentrations of 10<sup>7</sup> ml<sup>-1</sup>. Adjust the sample volume according to the bacterial concentration in your samples.
source_data.body: Note: ca. 20 ml of sample is required for samples with bacterial concentrations of 10<sup>7</sup> ml<sup>-1</sup>. Adjust the sample volume according to the bacterial concentration in your samples.

components.data:
Centrifuge samples using the following conditions (you can use a different rotor as long as it can reach the appropriate g-force): 
Rotor: Beckman SW 40 Ti
Temperature: 4ºC
Time: 1 hr
Speed: 20000 rpm (average force = 55000 xg)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Centrifuge samples using the following conditions (you can use a different rotor as long as it can reach the appropriate g-force): 
Rotor: Beckman SW 40 Ti
Temperature: 4ºC
Time: 1 hr
Speed: 20000 rpm (average force = 55000 xg)

source_data.annotation: Balance the rotor exactly with another sample or dummy sample.

components.data: After centrifugation, you can remove the sample and add more sample for additional centrifugation runs to achieve the required volume .

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Make 2 ml of 0.5% uranyl acetate with Q-water in a 4 ml culture tube using a stir bar to mix the sample on a stir plate for ~30 minutes to 1 hour.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Make 2 ml of 0.5% uranyl acetate with Q-water in a 4 ml culture tube using a stir bar to mix the sample on a stir plate for ~30 minutes to 1 hour.

components.data: Fill 3x 2 ml screw-cap tubes with Q-water.
components.name: Description

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Using tweezers, remove the piece of paper with the attached grids from the ultracentrifuge tube and place in a petri dish.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using tweezers, remove the piece of paper with the attached grids from the ultracentrifuge tube and place in a petri dish.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Using tweezers, remove a grid from the piece of paper (make sure the tape is not still attached to the grid).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using tweezers, remove a grid from the piece of paper (make sure the tape is not still attached to the grid).

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data:
Immerse the grid into the 0.5% uranyl acetate solution for 30 seconds (Figure 3)


Figure 3. Immersing the grid in the uranyl acetate solution.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Immerse the grid into the 0.5% uranyl acetate solution for 30 seconds (Figure 3)


Figure 3. Immersing the grid in the uranyl acetate solution.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Immerse the grid into the 1st tube of Q-water for 10 seconds.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Immerse the grid into the 1st tube of Q-water for 10 seconds.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Immerse the grid into the 2nd tube of Q-water for 10 seconds
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Immerse the grid into the 2nd tube of Q-water for 10 seconds

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Immerse the grid into the 3rd tube of Q-water for 10 seconds.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Immerse the grid into the 3rd tube of Q-water for 10 seconds.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Wick away liquid from the grid using a wedge of filter paper placed at the edge of the grid (Figure 4)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wick away liquid from the grid using a wedge of filter paper placed at the edge of the grid (Figure 4)

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

components.data: Place the grid in a grid box and allow to dry overnight, then store the grid in a desiccator until analysis.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the grid in a grid box and allow to dry overnight, then store the grid in a desiccator until analysis.

components.data: Preparing the grids
components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 19 of FVIC (Frequency of Visibly Infected Cells) Protocol

source_data.protocol_name_html: FVIC (Frequency of Visibly Infected Cells) Protocol
source_data.annotation: Do not put wet grids in a desiccator immediately as this can create “cracking” of the stain.
source_data.thread_text: Do not put wet grids in a desiccator immediately as this can create “cracking” of the stain.
source_data.body: Do not put wet grids in a desiccator immediately as this can create “cracking” of the stain.

components.data: Using a transmission electron microscope with 100 kV accelerating voltage, examine a grid at ~40000X.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using a transmission electron microscope with 100 kV accelerating voltage, examine a grid at ~40000X.

components.data: Grid analysis
components.name: Section

components.data:
Look at 800 cells per grid. Count how many cells have >5 viruses assembled within the cell (Figure 4)


Figure 4. Examples of cells that would be counted as visibly infected and not visibly infected.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Look at 800 cells per grid. Count how many cells have >5 viruses assembled within the cell (Figure 4)


Figure 4. Examples of cells that would be counted as visibly infected and not visibly infected.

source_data.annotation: Greater than 5” rule prevents you from mistaking cellular structures or extracellular viruses from intracellular viruses.

components.data: Determine burst size: Using the micrographs of visibly infected cells, count how many viruses are present inside of cells that are full of viruses.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Determine burst size: Using the micrographs of visibly infected cells, count how many viruses are present inside of cells that are full of viruses.

components.data: Grid analysis
components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 26 of FVIC (Frequency of Visibly Infected Cells) Protocol
source_data.protocol_name: FVIC (Frequency of Visibly Infected Cells) Protocol
source_data.protocol_name_html: FVIC (Frequency of Visibly Infected Cells) Protocol
source_data.annotation:
*Caveats:
- some cells can burst before they are full of viruses (thus, this is an overestimate of burst size)
- it may be impossible to count the total number of viruses within larger cells because they are overlapping one another (thus, this is an underestimate of burst size)
source_data.thread_text:
